_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Building Ventillation, Isolation valves, Monitor hydrants and UV/IR
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Plant 1.0 consists of a silane loading facility and a poly silicon unit running for analytical purposes only.  Note that this facility is covered by 29 CFR 1910.119, so most dates indicated below are the most recent review/revision of the item and not necessarily the date first in compliance.  The last PHA conducted for the Plant 1.0 Facility ? Silane storage, loading and venting portion of the process was April, 13, 2015.  The schedule for conducting the PHA is summarized in REC Procedure PSM 30.003 Process Hazard Analysis.  The major hazards, process controls, mitigation systems and monitoring/detection systems are identified considering all of the PHAs conducted on the covered process. Note that in all cases, major hazards were identified as those hazards possible in the absence of process controls, test and inspection programs, and mitigation systems.  

The following schedule is the date of the last PHA revalidations of covered processes in Plant 1.0:

?    02 & 08 Distillation ? 1/26/2015

?    Silane Storage & Loading ? 4/13/2015

?    TDF-A/C ? 9/16/2012

?    03 Process Headers ? 1/31/2011

?    Poly Wet Vacuum System ? 3/26/2014

?    Process Development Facility (Fluid Bed Reactor) ? 7/31/2013

_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Building ventilation and isolation valves; monitors and hydrants
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Process leak detection UV/IR; ultra sensitive smoke detection systems
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Plant 4.0 consists of a Silane production unit and a Silane Loading facility.  The silane production unit was commissioned and started up on June 23, 2010.  The company prevention program applies to the 4.0 plant including the silane plant and silane loading facility.  Both are covered by 29 CFR 1910.119.  The last PHA conducted was for the HSHS Facility the week of 7/15/2014.  During all PHAA?s the major hazards, process controls, mitigation systems, and monitoring/detection systems are identified.  Note that in all cases, A?major hazardsA? were identified as those hazards possible in the absence of process controls, test and inspection programs, and mitigation systems.     



The following final revalidation PHA's have been conducted prior to the startup for the 4.0 Silane facilities:

Hydrogenation                    10/10/2011

Distillation                     2/09/2012

Hot Oil                          2/09/2012

Silane Storage                   2/21/2013

Silane Refrigeration             5/21/2012

Metal Chloride Dryer             6/13/2011

Byproducts                       5/19/2014

HSHS                             7/15/2014



The following final revalidation PHAA?s have been conducted prior to the startup for the 4.0 Silane Loading facilities:

Loading                          8/26/2013

Loading Scrubber                 5/19/2014

Plant 3.0 consists of a silane production facility and a poly silicon production unit. The schedule for conducting the PHAA?s is summarized in REC Procedure PSM 30.003 Process Hazard Analysis.  The major hazards, process controls, mitigation systems, and monitoring/detection systems are identified considering all of the PHAs conducted on the covered process.  Note that in all cases, A?major hazardsA? were identified as those hazards possible in the absence of process controls, test and inspection programs, and mitigation systems.

_emerg_resp.CoordinatingAgencyName: Grant County Dept. of Emergency Mgt

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Information



Renewable Energy Corporation (REC) Silicon LLC Moses Lake, Washington facility is a manufacturer of silane and polycrystalline silicon for the electronics, solar and photovoltaic industry.  REC occupies a 194-acre plot, which is located 5 miles east of Moses Lake, Washington on Road "N" NE.  The neighborhood is predominantly agricultural with several food processing plants, another chemical manufacturing facility, an industrial insulation manufacturing facility, an industrial gas cylinder filling facility, gas manufacturing facility, and a corrugated cardboard production plant are in the vicinity.  REC silicon employs approximately 435 employees.  



Process Overview 



The REC Silicon facility in Moses Lake, WA is comprised of seven different production units: 1) Three Silane units, 2) Poly Reaction 3) Fluidized Bed Reaction  4)  Process Development Facility and 5) The silane loading Facility



The Silane Unit, through a series of chemical reactions and separation steps, converts metallurgical silicon and hydrogen to a high purity silane gas.  Intermediates produced in the process are trichlorosilane and dichlorosilane.  The Poly Reaction and Fluidized Bed Reactor Units use the silane and convert it into hydrogen and polycrystalline silicon.  The hydrogen is recycled back to the Silane Unit.  The Process Development Facility, which investigates new methods for producing polycrystalline silicon, also uses silane. Silane gas is also processed through the loading building where it is packaged for commerce in DOT approved tubular modules.



There is one covered "process" as defined by the RMP regulations at the Moses Lake facility.  This process includes the Silane, Poly and Fluid Bed Reaction production areas the Process Development Facility and the Silane loading facility (which are interconnected), and the silane module storage area located adjacent to the Silane loading building. Together these areas are identified as the Polysilicon Man

ufacturing process.



Chemicals: 



REC Silicon has identified the following chemicals and maximum on-site quantities, which trigger compliance with the Risk Management Program (RMP) standards, 40 CFR Part 68:



Silane  736,000 pounds

Flammable Mixture 1:  1,290,000 pounds



Note:  Flammable Mixture 1 may contain silane, dichlorosilane, trichlorosilane, and other non-RMP regulated materials (monochlorosilane and silicon tetrachloride).  



In addition to the above RMP-covered chemicals, REC Silicon has identified other potentially hazardous chemicals which could have either onsite or offsite impacts.  Risks from both these non RMP-covered chemicals as well as the RMP-covered chemicals are minimized using similar design standards, procedures, controls, mitigation measures, and emergency response procedures.   REC Silicon is also working with the local Department of Emergency Management and the Local Emergency Planning Committee to coordinate emergency planning and emergency response for all potentially hazardous chemicals.



Accident History



In the past five years REC Silicon has had no accidental releases meeting the criteria for reporting in the risk management.

 

Accidental Release Prevention Program



REC Silicon's accidental release prevention program is based on the following essential elements: hazard reviews of equipment and processes, preventative and predictive maintenance programs, a management of change program, operator job certification and performance testing, accurate operating procedures, internal and external auditing and inspection programs, accident and near-miss investigations, etc.  Advanced process monitoring and control systems are in use at the facility, and critical parameters are monitored with duplicate instrumentation including Layers of Protection Analysis, and Safety Instrumented Systems.  Loss of utilities is protected against through the use of installed and routinely tested back-up systems.  Engineering and design standa

rds ensure materials and equipment meet industry specifications.  REC Silicon is known as an industry leader in silane handling safety.



Emergency Response Program



REC Silicon's emergency response program has been coordinated with the local Department of Emergency Management and LEPC.  The program includes information on locations, quantities, and associated hazards of materials at the facility, as well as fixed and portable methods for containment and/or suppression of spills and releases, internal and external notification and communications procedures, alarm systems and evacuation plans.  The facility itself is designed with numerous mitigating features, including containment and diking, deluge systems for fire and vapor suppression, strategically-placed fire hydrants and fire monitors, and emergency scrubber systems.  Automatic and manual shutdown systems as well as automatic isolation valves are in place.  Back-up fire water supplies and firewater pumps are installed.  Emergency equipment is routinely maintained and tested.  In addition, REC Silicon maintains a highly trained emergency response team on-site 24-hours a day. The team performs realistic monthly drills and exercises, covering a variety of response scenarios such as spill containment and cleanup, vapor suppression, fire fighting, and response to injuries.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



REC Silicon continues to seek and identify opportunities to improve safety through process hazard analyses, safety reviews and inspections, internal and external audits, incident and near-miss investigations, employee and safety committee suggestions, increased employee awareness and involvement in Near Miss and Hazard Recognition daily auditing. Additionally, the facility has implemented a "Best Practices In Safety Leadership" Program to reach our goal of a Zero Incident Safety Culture" as characterized by a High Value for Safety and Very Low Incident Frequency Rates.
